skill.name: workflow-orchestration-patterns
skill.description: Design durable workflows with Temporal for distributed systems. Covers workflow vs activity separation, saga patterns, state management, and determinism constraints. Use when building long-running processes, distributed transactions, or microservice orchestration.
skill.summary: Design durable workflows with Temporal for distributed systems. Covers workflow vs activity separati...
skill.author: wshobson

security_audit.summary: This skill contains only documentation files (SKILL.md, plugin.json, marketplace-entry.json). No executable code, scripts, or network activity exist. It provides pure guidance about Temporal workflow patterns with no file system access or data handling capabilities.

content.value_statement: Distributed transactions fail without clear orchestration. This skill provides Temporal patterns for deterministic workflows, retries, and compensation actions.
actual_capabilities: Explain workflow versus activity separation and when to use each
Outline saga compensation steps with correct ordering for rollback
Describe entity workflow patterns using signals and queryable state
Define fan-out and fan-in for parallel task execution
Summarize retry policies, heartbeats, and idempotency requirements
limitations: Provides no executable code or SDK-specific implementation examples
Does not cover non-Temporal orchestration engines
Excludes real-time streaming or batch pipeline design

use_cases.title: Design payment orchestration
use_cases.description: Plan a multi-step payment workflow with compensations, retries, and idempotent activities.

use_cases.title: Model long-lived entities
use_cases.description: Choose entity workflows for accounts or carts with signals and queryable state.

use_cases.title: Harden failure recovery
use_cases.description: Define retry limits, backoff, and heartbeat policies for critical activities.

prompt_templates.title: Workflow or activity
prompt_templates.prompt: Classify each step of my order process as workflow or activity and explain why.

prompt_templates.title: Saga checklist
prompt_templates.prompt: Draft a saga plan for reserve inventory, charge payment, and ship order with compensations and idempotency rules.

prompt_templates.title: Parallel scaling
prompt_templates.prompt: Propose a fan-out and fan-in design for 500,000 tasks using child workflows and bounded workflow size.

prompt_templates.title: Versioning strategy
prompt_templates.prompt: Recommend a versioning approach for a long-running workflow update with backward compatibility constraints.

output_examples.input: Outline a Temporal saga for booking travel with rollback steps.
output: Reserve flight, compensate by canceling reservation
Book hotel, compensate by canceling booking
Charge payment, compensate by refunding payment
On failure, run compensations in reverse order (LIFO)

best_practices: Keep workflows deterministic and move all I/O to activities
Make activities idempotent, short-lived, and always configure timeouts
Use child workflows to scale large parallel workloads
anti_patterns: Calling external APIs directly from workflows
Using system time or random functions in workflows
Skipping compensation registration before executing a step

faq.question: Is this compatible with all Temporal SDKs?
faq.answer: Yes, the patterns are SDK agnostic and focus on architecture and design principles.

faq.question: What are the main limits covered?
faq.answer: It addresses determinism, payload size, retry behavior, and long-running execution constraints.

faq.question: How do I integrate this with existing services?
faq.answer: Use activities for external calls and keep workflows focused on orchestration and decision logic.

faq.question: Does it access or store my data?
faq.answer: No, this is documentation only and includes no code or data handling capabilities.

faq.question: What if my workflow fails repeatedly?
faq.answer: Use retry policies with limits, classify non-retryable errors, and add compensations for partial failures.

faq.question: How does it compare to Airflow or Kafka?
faq.answer: It targets long-running orchestration and distributed transactions, not batch pipelines or real-time streams.
